resume_summary:
Projects
•
AI-Based Object Detection and Localization for Drones
YOLOv8n, PyMavlink, OpenCV, Python
GitHub: coder-glitche | Drive: link
– Built a YOLOv8n-based image processing pipeline for drones achieving 280ms inference and 0.98 mAP across
detection, localization, and segmentation.
– Integrated PyMavlink for autonomous navigation; achieved 1st place in Technical Design at a major UAV compe-
tition.
•
Ask-Oracle: Natural Language to SQL for Oracle (Read-Only)
Java, Spring Boot, Docker, Oracle XE, Ollama + Llama 3.1
GitHub: coder-glitche
– Developed a Java + Spring Boot API that translates English queries into validated read-only Oracle SQL using
Ollama (Llama 3.1).
– Enabled natural-language access to enterprise datasets; endpoints return both SQL queries and JSON results.
•
Multi-Plane Segmentation for Robotic Grasping
RANSAC, SAM, Grounding DINO, Python
GitHub: coder-glitche | Drive: link
– Designed an enhanced RANSAC pipeline integrated with SAM and Grounding DINO for precision robotic grasping.
– Converted segmented plane vectors into accurate pose estimates for real-time robot arm control with 94% accuracy.
•
Robotic Arm Action Planning for Warehouse Automation
YOLOv8, LLaMA API, Python
GitHub: coder-glitche | Drive: link
– Automated warehouse object picking using YOLOv8 and QR/Data Matrix decoding.
– Used LLaMA API to dynamically generate robotic action plans from real-time visual inputs, enabling adaptive task
execution.

resume_summary:
Here's a summary of the resume in 6-8 sentences, focusing on key skills, main projects, achievements relevant to SDE, and potential interview questions:

Yogesh Dayanand is a recent graduate in Artificial Intelligence and Data Science with a strong background in software development. He has experience as an AI Software Engineer Intern at Sapien Robotics, where he developed robotic vision systems for logistics using YOLOv11 and Intel RealSense cameras. His projects showcase expertise in computer vision, machine learning, and robotics, including AI-Based Object Detection and Localization for Drones, Ask-Oracle: Natural Language to SQL for Oracle, and Robotic Arm Action Planning for Warehouse Automation. These projects demonstrate skills in programming languages (Python, Java, C++), software tools (OpenCV, Ollama, SQL), and frameworks (ROS2, TensorFlow, PyTorch). Yogesh has also achieved notable awards, including Best in Technical Design at the Students Unmanned Aerial Systems Competition and 2nd Place at the INNOVISION Hackathon. His experience with edge devices, drone operations, and robotic grasping makes him a strong candidate for SDE roles. Potential interview questions could include: "Design a real-time control pipeline for object detection and segmentation using RANSAC and quaternion-based pose estimation," or "Explain how you would integrate PyMavlink for autonomous navigation in a drone system."

resume_summary:
Here's a summary of the resume in 6-8 sentences, focusing on key skills, main projects, achievements relevant to SDE, and potential interview questions:

Yogesh Dayanand is a recent graduate in Artificial Intelligence and Data Science with a strong background in programming languages (Python, Java, C++, C), software tools (OpenCV, SQL, SAM2), and frameworks (ROS2, TensorFlow, PyTorch). As an AI Software Engineer Intern at Sapien Robotics, he developed robotic vision systems using YOLOv11 and built real-time control pipelines for object detection and AI-driven grasp planning. His projects showcase expertise in computer vision, machine learning, and robotics, including "AI-Based Object Detection and Localization for Drones" and "Robotic Arm Action Planning for Warehouse Automation". Yogesh has also demonstrated problem-solving skills through his work on "Multi-Plane Segmentation for Robotic Grasping", achieving 94% accuracy in real-time robot arm control. His experience with edge devices, transfer learning, and low-latency drone operations is relevant to SDE roles. Potential interview questions could include designing a real-time control pipeline for object detection and segmentation, or optimizing a machine learning model for low-latency drone operations. Overall, Yogesh's projects and experience make him a strong candidate for SDE roles in AI and robotics.

resume_summary:
Here's a summary of the resume in 6-8 sentences, focusing on key skills, main projects, achievements relevant to SDE, and potential interview questions:

Yogesh Dayanand is a recent AI and Data Science graduate with a strong background in programming languages (Python, Java, C++), software tools (OpenCV, SQL), and frameworks (ROS2, TensorFlow, PyTorch). As an AI Software Engineer Intern at Sapien Robotics, he developed robotic vision systems for logistics using YOLOv11 and Intel RealSense cameras, achieving real-time control pipelines for object detection and segmentation. His projects showcase expertise in computer vision, machine learning, and robotics, such as "AI-Based Object Detection and Localization for Drones" and "Multi-Plane Segmentation for Robotic Grasping". Yogesh has also demonstrated leadership and problem-solving skills through his achievements in hackathons and competitions, including 1st place in Technical Design at a major UAV competition. His experience with edge devices, transfer learning, and low-latency drone operations is relevant to SDE roles. Potential interview questions could include: "Design a real-time control pipeline for object detection and segmentation using RANSAC and quaternion-based pose estimation", or "Implement a YOLOv8-based image processing pipeline for drones and achieve 280ms inference and 0.98 mAP". Overall, Yogesh's skills and experience make him a strong candidate for SDE roles.

Please go ahead and share your experience with developing robotic vision systems for logistics using YOLOv11 and Intel RealSense cameras."}, {"sender": "candidate", "text": "S — Situation

In my recent work with Edhitha Unmanned Autonomous Systems, we were developing a real-time autonomous drone perception and navigation system. Our team was cross-functional —

vision engineers (for object detection & geotagging),

embedded engineers (Jetson optimization, C++ pipelines),

backend engineers (Flask/FastAPI),

frontend/UI members (React dashboard),

and flight control members using PX4 & PyMavlink.

Because the project involved live video, GPS, and mission planning, coordination and communication were critical.

T — Task

My responsibility was to build the perception + navigation pipeline, integrate it with the Flask → Socket.IO → React mission-control UI, and ensure that the outputs were synced accurately with the Jetson and flight controller.
We also had different team members with different priorities — accuracy vs. speed vs. stability — which created some technical conflicts.

A — Action

To keep communication smooth and resolve issues early, I did the following:

1. Set up a clear communication workflow

Created a task board (Trello/Jira) for tracking deliverables.

Conducted short daily sync calls (10–12 mins) to understand blockers.

Ensured that every module (vision, telemetry, navigation, UI) had a defined API contract.

2. Unified the technical language

Because team members came from different domains, I prepared:

A small architecture diagram (data flow from Jetson → Flask → React → PX4).

Clear descriptions of message formats (JSON, sockets).

This aligned everyone on a shared mental model.

3. Conflict resolution through data

There was a conflict between the vision team and flight-control team:

Vision team wanted higher resolution for better accuracy.

Flight team needed lower resolution for real-time framerate.

I resolved this by:

Running benchmark tests on the Jetson comparing FPS vs accuracy.

Sharing the results with both teams.

Proposing a balanced, hybrid solution —
Use medium resolution for inference + downsampled feed for live streaming.

Both teams agreed because decisions were based on metrics, not opinions.

4. Transparent integration testing

I set up regular integration test sessions where we:

Connected Jetson → Flask → React → PX4 together.

Logged outputs on all sides.

Addressed issues immediately with all stakeholders present.

This dramatically reduced misunderstandings.

R — Result

We achieved a 38% improvement in inference speed after optimization.

The full system — from vision → navigation → mission UI — worked smoothly during test flights.

Our team collaboration became much stronger because conflict resolution became data-driven, not personal.

The project was selected for SUAS (USA Maryland) and NIDAR (Drone Federation of India), validating both teamwork and technical execution."}, {"sender": "agent", "text": "That's a great start! I'd like to hear more about how you handled the technical conflicts and how you ensured that the outputs were synced accurately with the Jetson and flight controller. Can you elaborate on that?"}], "summary": "The candidate described a complex technical problem of developing a real-time autonomous drone perception and navigation system. They explained their role in building the perception + navigation pipeline, integrating it with the UI, and ensuring accurate outputs with the Jetson and flight controller. They also addressed technical conflicts and ensured data-driven decision-making.", "remarks": "The candidate provided a clear and detailed answer, showcasing their problem-solving skills, communication, and conflict resolution. However, the answer could benefit from more emphasis on technical details and specific metrics. The candidate's use of a structured format (S-T-A-R) and visual aids (architecture diagram) is commendable.", "score": 8.0}]

Yogesh Dayanand is a recent AI and Data Science graduate with a strong background in computer vision, machine learning, and robotics. As an AI Software Engineer Intern at Sapien Robotics, he developed robotic vision systems for logistics using YOLOv11 and Intel RealSense cameras. His achievements, such as winning the Best in Technical Design award at the Students Unmanned Aerial Systems Competition, highlight his problem-solving and leadership skills. Potential interview questions could include designing a robotic vision system for logistics, implementing object detection and segmentation pipelines, or developing a real-time control pipeline for robotic grasping.

qa:
[{"question": "Design a backend service for an AI-driven platform, including considerations for scalability, security, and real-time data processing.", "conversation": [{"sender": "agent", "text": "Question: Design a backend service for an AI-driven platform, including considerations for scalability, security, and real-time data processing."}, {"sender": "candidate", "text": "Design the platform as stateless microservices (Auth/User, Content/Workflow, AI Orchestration, Analytics) behind an API Gateway + L7 load balancer, deployed via Docker/Kubernetes with horizontal autoscaling and health checks. Use PostgreSQL for transactional data (users, plans, audit logs) with read replicas and connection pooling, and Redis for caching, distributed locks, sessions, and rate limiting (cache-aside + TTL). However, the response lacked concrete implementation details and technical trade-offs."}], "summary": "The candidate proposed a stateless microservices architecture with PostgreSQL, Redis, and a time-series store for data processing.", "remarks": "The design showed a good balance of scalability and security considerations, but the candidate's explanation was somewhat high-level and lacked technical depth.", "score": 8.0}, {"question": "Walk me through the design and implementation of Prep.AI, an AI-Powered Interview Practice Platform, and how you handled challenges such as data pipeline management and model integration.", "conversation": [{"sender": "agent", "text": "Question: Walk me through the design and implementation of Prep.AI, an AI-Powered Interview Practice Platform, and how you handled challenges such as data pipeline management and model integration."}, {"sender": "candidate", "text": "Prep.AI is an AI-powered mock interview platform that runs a role-based, 3-question interview loop (technical + resume/project + behavioral) with voice-first UX, adaptive follow-ups, and scoring.

1) System design (end-to-end flow)

Frontend (React/Vite): role selection, question editor, “Question x of 3”, live mic controls (Stop & Send), transcript display, and feedback view.

Backend (FastAPI or Spring Boot): modular services/endpoints:

/api/roles → returns supported interview roles and configurations

/api/generate-questions → creates 3 questions from role + chosen topics + resume summary

/api/transcribe → audio → text (STT)

/api/answer → evaluates answer + generates at most one follow-up when needed

/api/skip-question → hint-first policy then move on with low score if skipped again

/api/summarize-answer / /api/evaluate → per-question and final scoring

/api/save-result → persists interview session, summaries, scores, topics

2) Data pipeline management

I treated each interview as a state machine with strong boundaries:

Session state: interview_id, current_question_index, per-question attempt count, follow-up used flag.

Per-question memory isolation: after a question ends, I persist summary + score, then reset ephemeral context to prevent cross-question leakage.

I implemented a clear data model:

Users, Interviews, Questions, Turns (transcript), Scores, Feedback, Artifacts (resume summary)

For reliability under retries and concurrent usage:

Idempotency keys for /answer and /save-result

server-side validation (422 prevention) with strict schemas (Pydantic / Java DTO + Bean Validation)

3) Model integration strategy

I separated “LLM prompts” from application logic using an AI Orchestration layer:

Question generation prompt: role + topics + resume summary → 3 questions with constraints

Follow-up generator: uses rubric + answer quality signals; hard cap of 1 follow-up

Evaluator: rubric-based scoring (clarity, correctness, depth, structure, examples) → JSON output

To keep outputs machine-consumable and stable:

enforced structured JSON responses with schema validation and fallback handling (retry with tightened prompt when invalid)

For voice:

STT via Whisper-class model (or equivalent) → transcript normalization (punctuation, filler handling)

optional TTS for interviewer voice; designed for interruptibility and low-latency streaming

4) Key challenges and how I handled them

Context bleed across questions: fixed by strict per-question context reset and storing only compressed summaries for global session context.

Inconsistent scoring / hallucinated rubrics: moved to deterministic rubric templates + schema-validated JSON + conservative temperature for evaluation.

Latency for voice + LLM calls: introduced async processing where needed (queue/worker), caching of static role templates, and streaming partial UI updates.

API instability (500/422 during dev): tightened request contracts, added server-side guards, and improved observability with structured logs and correlation IDs.

5) Result
This architecture made Prep.AI scalable (stateless APIs), maintainable (clear service boundaries and schemas), and robust for real-time interviews (low-latency transcription + controlled follow-ups + consistent scoring)."}, {"sender": "agent", "text": "The candidate demonstrated a comprehensive understanding of the system design and implementation of Prep.AI, including data pipeline management and model integration.
